docs.lead_paragraph: Eva Hebenstreit remembers a trip to Israel in January 1986, when her 71-year-old husband, Werner, could not get across the street before the light changed. ''He was a cripple,'' said Mrs. Hebenstreit. ''A permanent coronary cripple.''

headline.main: Medicare to Run Diet Experiment for Critically Ill

docs.abstract: Medicare program, in first-even experiment on critically ill elderly people, will undertake larges-scale test of low-fat diet and exercise program developed by Dr Dean Ornish, who for more than 20 years has studied whether changes in diet and daily activities can reverse coronary heart disease; Ornish program is a radical one, combining extremely low-fat, vegetarian diet with exercise, meditation and smoking cessation; enrollment of volunteers in Medicare experiment starts on April 10; nutrition and exercise experiment is designed to determine whether drastic changes in lifestyle and eating habits can prevent need for angioplasty and heart bypass surgery; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Eva Hebenstreit remembers a trip to Israel in January 1986, when her 71-year-old husband, Werner, could not get across the street before the light changed.    ''He was a cripple,'' said Mrs. Hebenstreit. ''A permanent coronary cripple.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Scientists think they may now know what makes a mouse head straight for the cookie jar. Of greater interest to the mouse, perhaps, they have also figured out a way to let him indulge as often as he likes and still be able to fit back through his mouse hole. In the first case, researchers at an American Chemical Society conference reported that they were zeroing in on the gene that may explain why mice are so partial to sweets. In the second, researchers at the University of Dentistry and Medicine of New Jersey, writing in the journal Nature Genetics, say they have bred a genetically modified mouse that can eat without getting fat.

headline.main: Of Thinner People and a Fat-Free Mouse

docs.abstract: Scientists study mice genes in search of links to obesity, and whether there is possible universal attraction to sweets (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Twelve to 14 percent of American children ages 5 to 12 spend some time home alone after school, a new study has found, but the period without adult supervision averages only an hour, most of the children are older, and many seem to welcome a measure of privacy and independence. Only 1 percent of the youngest children in a national sampling, ages 5 to 7, were left in so-called self-care, while 8 percent of the children 8 to 10 years old were in self-care, according to the study by the University of Michigan's Institute for Social Research. The biggest share of the children spending time alone was older, about 23 percent of the 11- and 12-year-olds in the study.

headline.main: What Children Do When Home and Alone

docs.abstract: New study finds that 12 to 14 percent of American children ages 5 to 12 spend some time home alone after school, but period without adult supervision averages only an hour, most of children are older and many seem to welcome measure of privacy and independence; only 1 percent of youngest children in national sampling, ages 5 to 7, were let in so-called self-care, while 8 percent of children 8 to 10 years old were in self-care; what children do at home after school discussed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans are living with pain, and are resigned to that condition, a new study says. The Arthritis Foundation reported last week that a Gallup poll of about 2,000 people found that regular pain was a pervasive part of American life, but that few people sought medical attention for it. Sixty percent of those surveyed agreed that pain was ''just something you have to live with.''

headline.main: Many in America Are Resigned to Pain

docs.abstract: New study finds that millions of Americans are living with pain, and are resigned to that condition; Arthritis Foundation reports that Gallup poll of about 2,000 people found that regular pain is pervasive part of American life, but that few people seek medical attention for it; 42 percent of adults surveyed report experiencing pain every day, 89 percent say they did so every month (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: It should be no surprise to viewers of the hit movie ''Erin Brockovich'' that the science portrayed in the movie is not really science. After all, this is a major motion picture coming out of Hollywood. It comes from a fairy tale land where women are abnormally beautiful, men are lusciously handsome, where sex is unusually profligate and violence casual and frequent. So if audiences are willing to suspend disbelief in every other arena, why should anyone care about something so dull as the veracity of the scientific methodology?

headline.main: A Hit Movie Is Rated 'F' In Science

docs.abstract: Many scientists are offended by image of science presented in movie Erin Brockovich; they contend that science presented in movie, which links wide array of illnesses in Hinkley, Calif, to groundwater pollution, crosses line from verity to hyperbole and indoctrination (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers believe they may have found an unusual new tool, magnets, to help in the war against cancer. Hoping to increase the effectiveness of chemotherapy treatments, scientists at the University of California at Los Angeles attached the anticancer drug doxorubicin to microscopic particles of a magnetic material. They then used a much larger magnet to help concentrate the medicine at the site of the tumor.

headline.main: Zooming In on Tumors, With Magnets

docs.abstract: Researchers believe they may have found an unusual new tool, magnets, to help increase effectiveness of chemotherapy treatments in fighting cancerous tumors (S)
docs.snippet: Researchers believe they may have found an unusual new tool, magnets, to help in the war against cancer.    Hoping to increase the effectiveness of chemotherapy treatments, scientists at the University of California at Los Angeles attached the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Are you filled with dread instead of delight about the arrival of spring, anticipating the sneezes, runny nose and itchy eyes that are the hallmarks of seasonal allergic rhinitis? Well, suffer no more. There is now a wide array of treatments, over the counter and prescription, that can suppress the annoying symptoms of spring (and fall) allergies, which can interfere with sleep, work and enjoyment of life and increase your vulnerability to colds, sinusitis and other respiratory infections. You are hardly alone. Ten to 30 percent of Americans are allergic to wind-swept pollen from trees, grasses, weeds and/or molds. In spring, you can blame such trees as alder, ash, birch, cedar, elm, hazel, maple, oak, olive, pecan, sycamore and walnut. In summer, common allergens include grasses like timothy, ryegrass, Bermuda grass, English plantain and sheep sorrel. And, of course, there's fall, with pollen from ragweed, sage and Russian thistle the common culprits.

headline.main: Breaking the Cycle of Seasonal Sneezes

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on prospects for breaking cycle of seasonal allergies, and the attendant sneezes, runny nose and itchy eyes; comments on the allergic response, prevention and treatment; comments on nasal sprays, antihistamines, decongestants and immunotherapy; chart shows allergy seasons (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: City dwellers get sick more often than their rural counterparts. Well-educated adults are healthier than those without high school diplomas.

headline.main: Most Likely to Feel Healthy: Educated Rural People

docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention release five-year study showing that city dwellers get sick more often than their rural counterparts; finds that well-educated adults are healthier than those without high school educations; finds that people living in poverty are sick most often; in some pockets of high unemployment, residents report feeling unhealthy 20 days a month; for general population, average number of unhealthy days was 5.3; people in South Dakota feel the best, reporting just four unhealthy days a month (M)
docs.snippet: City dwellers get sick more often than their rural counterparts.    Well-educated adults are healthier than those without high school diplomas.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

docs.lead_paragraph: As new drugs to treat and even prevent Alzheimer's disease make their way through the pipeline, a basic medical issue has remained unresolved: how can doctors know which patients to medicate if they are not yet showing clear-cut symptoms? Now researchers believe they may find an answer in the magnetic resonance imaging machines. The findings are reported in a new study paid for by the National Institute on Aging and appearing in this month's issue of the Annals of Neurology.

headline.main: Scans Yield Clues to Early Alzheimer's

docs.lead_paragraph: Smoking while pregnant has long been linked to general problems like premature deliveries and babies with low birth weights, but a new study reports that it may also be linked to two specific birth defects: cleft palate and cleft lip. Even relatively few cigarettes -- 1 to 10 a day -- may increase the chances that an infant will need surgery to repair an improperly formed mouth or lip, the researchers say. The study was reported in a recent issue of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery, the journal of the American Society of Plastic Surgeons.

headline.main: Linking Cleft Palates and Smoking Moms

docs.abstract: New study finds that smoking while pregnant may be linked to two specific birth defects: cleft palate and cleft lip; photo (S)
